Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Geological Analysis To Determine Environmental Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
According to researchers, humans have entered the Anthropocene - a period of time when human action dominates natural processes. Yet, no one is quite sure when or how humans have arrived at this critical junction in time. Some researchers argue that the Anthropocene is recent, while others argue that it is thousands of years old. Archaeology is well situated to resolve this debate and provide historical insight into this problem. In particular, the investigators will use the early and rich archaeological record of China to better document the origins of the Anthropocene. This study uses a series of buried soils as a record of ancient environmental conditions, helping to put environmental changes now happening in China in a historical context. As part of this project, the investigators will help train Chinese collaborators interested in build the first reference collection of archaeologically important soil samples collected from Henan, China. The investigators will foster an exchange of perspectives, knowledge, and data between Chinese and American scholars necessary to answer this problem.

Under the direction of Dr. Tristram Kidder, Mr. Michael Storozum will use an extraordinarily preserved record of buried soils in Neihuang County, Henan, China to better document the origins of the Anthropocene to answer this specific research question. From two localities in Neihuang County, Anshang and Sanyangzhuang, the investigators will collect and analyze a continuous series of samples with a variety of scientific methods including X-ray florescence, electron microprobe, grain size distribution analysis, loss-on-ignition, magnetic susceptibility, and soil micromorphology to identify signatures of past human land use. Additionally, the investigators will refine the chronology at both Sanyangzhuang and Anshang with accelerator mass spectrometry dating of radiocarbon samples. By identifying signatures of past human land use, the investigators will be able to assess how humans transformed the natural environment of ten thousand years ago into the environments of the Anthropocene. This project will provide the data for Mr. Storozum's doctoral dissertation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, the term “Anthropocene” that describes a new geological era characterized by extensive human impacts on the environment has gone mainstream. Although both scientists and science news outlets now use the Anthropocene to describe many unexplored aspects of the relationships between humans and the environment, many scientific questions regarding the origins and development of the Anthropocene remain unclear. Archaeologists have argued that the Anthropocene began thousands of years ago with the development of agriculture, but some earth scientists remain skeptical of the assertion that so few people could exert significant changes on a geological time scale. This NSF funded project examined the effects human habitation had on the sediments and soils in Northern China, one of the most densely occupied places on the planet throughout history.

To ascertain the scale and extent of human impact on natural geological processes, the investigators on this project identified several archaeological sites in Northern China’s Henan Province great potential to serve as archives of some of the human behaviors that started the transformation of natural environment into what scientists now recognize as the Anthropocene. During the time of this grant, we investigated two archaeological sites named Sanyangzhuang (meaning “Three Sheep Village”) and Anshang (meaning “On the River Bank”) to compare the geological and archaeological similarities found in the soils and sediments at each location. In collaboration with archaeologists at the Henan Provincial Institute of Cultural Relics and Archaeology, we used the latest developments in geological methods, including Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), soil micromorphology, and radiocarbon dating, to develop a detailed record of environmental change and human activity. By using in a combination of these different methods at two similar sites, we are able to compare results to ensure that they are replicable and reproducible.  

The primary scientific outcomes from our investigations at both Anshang and Sanyangzhuang, suggest that starting around 3000 years ago, humans had a significant impact on many aspects of the environment, including the rate of sediment deposition, the process of soil formation, and the natural topography of the North China Plain. Based on the results of our radiocarbon analysis of sediments from Anshang and Sanyangzhuang, we argue that around 3000 years ago, the Yellow River deposited more and more sediment at both Sanyangzhuang and Anshang. One potential reason for this change may be the increased availability of the iron tools, such as the plow and ax, which expanding the amount of arable land on the friable Loess Plateau, the primary sediment source of the Yellow River. Our geochemical and microscopic work on soils found at both Anshang and Sanyangzhuang also indicate greater amounts of human disturbance starting around 3000 years ago. In the buried soils identified at Anshang and Sanyangzhuang, the elemental concentration of heavy metals (Pb, Cu, Zn) and metalloids (As) increased relative to the underlying natural soil that dates to a period before significant human occupation in the region (ca. 10,000 years ago). Microscopic analysis also shows features in the soils that the naked eye cannot observe in the field, such as rolled angular clumps of clay that are not a product of natural processes. Human disturbance became more pronounced in the stratigraphic sections that dated to the late historic period (ca. 1000 years ago), including an earthen construction feature found at Anshang.

The project had many institution building outcomes that will serve to further connect the American and Chinese academy. In particular, we introduced many new aspects of the combined science of geology and archaeology to our Chinese collaborators. Our project introduced the field of geoarchaeology to Mr. Liu Haiwang, the director of the Henan Provincial Institute of Cultural Relics and Archaeology, who is now an active collaborator on many archaeological projects that have a significant geological component. Not only have we introduced many Chinese students and professional archaeologists to the field of geoarchaeology, this project has included the active participation of students from Washington University in St. Louis.

In summary, the goal of this project was to examine the geological consequences of the Anthropocene in one of the most densely populated places on the planet. Our primary scientific outcomes contribute to both the academic and public discussion concerning the timing and nature of the Anthropocene. Our results show that humans had significant environmental impacts in Northern China around 3000 years ago, unlike other places in the world that have environmental archives of human environmental impacts that start fairly recently. Our institutional building efforts have also forged even stronger ties between American and Chinese research institutes, whose mutual efforts to understand global environmental change in the Anthropocene are increasingly important
